Name: Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid
Description: Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid is a perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid that is butane-1-sulfonic acid in which all of the hydrogens of the butyl group have been replaced by fluorines. It has a role as a surfactant.

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Braune BM, Letcher RJ; Environ Sci Technol 47: 616-24 (2013) (2) Falandysz J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 748-51 (2006) (3) Holmstrom KE, Berger U; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5879-84 (2008) (4) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-31 (2007) (5) Wang Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 8146-51 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.1 ng/g wet weight) in northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) and thick-billed murre (Uria lomvia) eggs sampled 1971-2009 from Prince Leopold Island, Nunavut, Canada; was detected in northern fulmar at 0.57 ng/g wet weight in 2011 and murre at 0.04 and 0.07 ng/g wet weight in 2010 and 2011, respectively; black guillemot (Cepphus grylle), black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) and glaucous gull (Larus hyperboreus) eggs sampled in 2008 did not contain perfluorobutanesulfonic acid(1). Perfluorobutanesulfonoic acid was not detected (detection limit 2 pg/mL) in blood samples from 16 eider duck (Sommateria mollisima), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003(2). Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was not detected (detection limit ng/g) in the muscle (0.87), kidney (0.10), adult liver (0.19), chick liver (0.06) or egg (0.15) of common guillemot (Uria aalge) samples from Stora Karlso Island in the Baltic Sea collected in 1989(3). Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was not detected in cormorants, racoon dog, eagle or large-bill crow collected from Japan(4). Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.01 ng/g wet weight) in eggs of little egret (Egretta garzetta), night heron (Nycticorax nycticorax) and great egret (Ardea alba) from Quanzhou, Xiamen, and Hong Kong, South China; respective sampling dates were March-May 2004, March-May 2004 and March-May 2006(5).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-31 (2007)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was detected in market fish livers collected in Japan at the following concentrations(1):
fish_seafood_concentrations.Table: [{'Fish': 'Scad', 'Number': 3, 'Concn (ng/g wet/wt)': '<7.5'}, {'Fish': 'Sand fish', 'Number': 7, 'Concn (ng/g wet/wt)': '<6.4'}, {'Fish': 'Jack mackerel', 'Number': 3, 'Concn (ng/g wet/wt)': '<5.8'}, {'Fish': 'Rainbow trout', 'Number': 3, 'Concn (ng/g wet/wt)': '<6.4'}, {'Fish': 'Sardine', 'Number': 3, 'Concn (ng/g wet/wt)': '<6.3'}]

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Stock NL et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3529-36 (2007) (2) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-31 (2007)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Sediment samples from Resolute, Char and Amituk lakes on Cornwallis Island, Nunavut, Canada contained perfluorobutanesulfonic acid at <0.029-0.11, <1.1 and <0.046-0.068 ng/g dry weight, respectively(1). Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid was detected at <0.1-<1.1 ng/g dry weight (quantification limit 2.2 ng/g dry weight) in sediment samples from Kamo, Uji, Tenjin, Katsura and Osaka rivers, Japan; samples were collected Feb-March 2005 or Dec 2003(2).
